title: Between 1 July 2019 and 30 June 2020, will an armed group from Afghanistan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Afghanistan?
preds: Afghanistan has few other wars taking place to outside countries and from within too. Systematically killing that much is I think little far fetched and may not happen.

For this week’s forecast, the key elements that I used in my determination are from the early warning project. This first data point, or consideration, that I used was that statistically mass killing are rare- on average barely over 1% of countries see a new mass killing in any given year. This informs me that there is a 90% + given chance that any given country would not experience a new mass killing. Therefore, there is a greater probability that a Afghanistan will not. So, I put my first assumption as a 2% chance of YES
For my second consideration, I evaluate that the EWP assessed Afghanistan as the 2nd at most risk country out of a mass killing with a roughly 1 in 4 chance (24.1%). Using this I increase my likelihood to approximately 14% with the previous information. For my third consideration, I look at historical data from 2017. In 2017, civilian deaths resulting from aerial operations from government and international forces increased by 50%. Since military forces or police can be included in the category for an “armed group” and that political and international conflict can predicate an increase militia and insurgent activity, I adjust this information an increase from 14% to 19%. 
Finally, researching recent news articles, US military forces have been killed within the week, and peace talks between the U.S. and the Taliban have come to a halt. A top U.S. general warns that there can be an increase in violence as the elections near. This increases my total percent from 19% to 22%. (https://www.armytimes.com/news/your-army/2019/09/16/us-troop-killed-in-action-in-afghanistan/)
As the Taliban regain territory, the number of civilians at risk of possible war crimes and crimes against humanity continues to increase.
Afghanistan does not have a central government to systematically kill a civilians. Though, thousands will die.

The phrasing of the question is somewhat vague (there isn't always a clear distinction between the intentional targeting of civilians in war and ambivalence of civilian casualties) therefore I consider attacks conducted by both Afghan National Government forces, the Taliban, and other belligerents that are conducted without deference to the well-being of civilians to qualify as a constituting part of a 'systemic campaign against civilians.'  Key factors in gauging the likelihood of a campaign killing more than a thousand civilians hedge on a number of factors:   •	The possibility of a cease-fire deal between the Taliban and the Afghan National Government 
•	The length of time before a cease-fire deal between the Taliban and the Afghan National Government 
o	(The Taliban have already demonstrated a reliance on wide-spread violence to secure a better-negotiating position prior to a deal) 
•	The possibility of a government collapse (with or without a ceasefire) 
•	The possibility of major splinter in the Taliban in Afghanistan
•	The emergence of another major militant group/or resurgence of ISIL in Afghanistan  Based on current trends of violence in Afghanistan (August 2019) an average of 74 people were killed every day (with one fifth being civilians) - holding all things equal, we would anticipate another 27,010 deaths over the next calendar year, with at least 5,402 of those being civilians. •	While it’s difficult to determine whether those killed in August 2019 died in attacks that qualify as part of a ‘systemic campaign against civilians’ there are some signs that many of the attacks that have the highest rates of civilian fatalities are the result of deliberate targeting. 
•	The upcoming election later this month (September 2019) will also likely feature a Taliban lead effort to deliberately target civilians (In 2018, the Taliban claimed it conducted attacks on 318 polling locations) this trend, should a lasting ceasefire fail to manifest seems likely to continue into future years. --- 
updated based on the collapse of talks with Taliban and Afghan/US government efforts to target the Taliban and Taliban defections to ISIL.

With eace talks and more than a few envoys dead we're back on familiar territory. Taliban will isolate populations geographically over the winter and assinate the bovernment officials , install their Shadow Governors etc. and pity the first ANA troops to return in the spring. The body count however may not get reported in this time frame and require a later revision.

The likelihood is low while the US and Taliban are negotiating and resolving US withdrawal from Afghanistan.  The Taliban will not want to damage their position by attacking civilians while their opponents will tend to focus on the active Taliban forces they can identify.  After the US withdrawal much greater levels of violence can be expected, including against civilians.

Not sure I believe peace is breaking out in Afghanistan but slim odds this is the end of the start or the start of the end or something. Perhaps meddling by Pakistan ISI and others will decrease (unlikely but one can hope). Per the Economist:
“Prominent Afghans and Taliban representatives settled on a “road map for peace”, a significant step towards ending the 18-year-long war. After two days of peace talks in Qatar both sides agreed to reduce “civilian casualties to zero” and guarantee the security of schools, hospitals and other public institutions. US-Taliban talks resume today, over America’s withdrawal from the country.“
